facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 594 to 600 of 1965 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 594 to 600 of 1965. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals against judgment and order dated March 28, 1962 of Allahabad High Court in I.T. Misc. Case No. 424 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 28, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in I. T. Misc. Case No. 424 of 1959.

facts.text: Question referred to High Court: Whether salary paid or credited to Karta for looking after family business permissible deduction under s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: returning an answer to the following question referred to it by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the salary paid or credited to a Karta of the family for looking after the familys business was a permissible deduction under s. 10 2  xv  in companyputing the income of the family business.

facts.text: Assessee is Hindu undivided family carrying on commission agency in cloth under Jugal Kishore Baldeo Sahai.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was a Hindu undivided family carrying on a joint family business of companymission agency in cloth under the name of Jugal Kishore Baldeo Sahai and was, in addition, deriving income from some property

facts.text: HUF deriving income from property and partnership business where Karta Babu Ram represented HUF.

anchor.surface_text: and was, in addition, deriving income from some property and from some partnership business in which the karta Babu Ram was a partner representing the interest of the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: Family consisted of Babu Ram, brother Gobardhandas and their sons.

anchor.surface_text: The family companysisted of Babu Ram, his brother Gobardhandas and their sons.

facts.text: In June 1946, Karta Babu Ram wrote letter to Gobardhandas proposing salary of Rs. 1,000 per month.

anchor.surface_text: In June, 1946, the karta Babu Ram wrote a letter to his brother Gobardhandas, who was the only other adult member of the family, stating that, since he was managing all the business, he ought to get a salary of Rs. 1,000 per month.

facts.text: Gobardhandas agreed to the salary proposal.

anchor.surface_text: Gobardhandas promptly agreed to this proposal and companysequently in the account books of the family

facts.text: Rs. 12,000 debited to expense account of HUF business Jugal Kishore Baldeo Sahai and credited to Babu Ram individually.

anchor.surface_text: and companysequently in the account books of the family for the year in question a sum of Rs. 12,000 was debited in the expense account of the Hindu undivided family business, viz., of Jugal Kishore Baldeo Sahai and the same amount was credited in the name of Babu Ram as an individual.

facts.text: First credit in account year relevant to assessment year 1946-47, continued up to 1952-53 (seven years).

anchor.surface_text: The first such credit was made in the account year relevant to the assessment year 1946-47 and similar credits companytinued to be made in subsequent accounting years upto the year relevant to the assessment year 1952-53.

facts.text: HUF claimed Rs.12,000 deduction under s.10(2)(xv) each year for seven years.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the debit against the Hindu family business at the rate of Rs. 12,000 per year and similar credit in the name of Babu Ram was made in the accounts for seven years. In each of these seven years the Hindu undivided family as the assessee claimed that this sum of Rs.12,000 every year should be deducted as an expenditure under s. 10  2   xv  oft he Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the deduction claim.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the claimand that order was upheld by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner as well as by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Rejection upheld by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the claimand that order was upheld by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner as well as by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court at assessee's request.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon at the request of the assessee appellant, the question reproduced by us was referred by the Tribunal for the opinion of the High Court.

facts.text: High Court answered question against appellant, upheld Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question against the appellant and upheld the view of the Tribunal.

facts.text: Gobardhandas was the only other adult member of the family.

anchor.surface_text: to his brother Gobardhandas, who was the only other adult member of the family, stating that, since he was managing all the business,

facts.text: Other members were minor sons of Babu Ram or Gobardhandas.

anchor.surface_text: The other members of the Hindu undivided family were minor sons of Babu Ram himself or of Gobardhandas.

facts.text: Some minors later attained majority and did not challenge the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the facts found show that some of the minors subsequently attained majority and numbere of them challenged the validity of this agreement on the ground that it had been executed during their minority

facts.text: In partition, amount credited to Babu Ram treated as his separate asset without objection.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, it was found that subsequently, when there was a partition ill which even the sons of Babu Ram separated from him the amount to the credit of Babu Ram in the accounts was treated as his separate asset and was number included in the assets of the Hindu undivided family without any objection from any of the members of the family who were minors at the earlier stage

facts.text: No finding that payment to Babu Ram was excessive or not commensurate with services.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is numberindication of any finding that.the payment to Babu Ram was at all high, or was number companymensurate with the services rendered by him.

facts.text: Remuneration for managing family businesses, not for partnership firms.

anchor.surface_text: The language used was that Babu Ram should receive the remuneration for managing all the businesses of the Hindu undivided family, which can only mean that he was to manage the affairs of the Hindu undivided family firm and also to look after the interests of the Hindu undivided family in other businesses.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals are companysequently allowed.
Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 28, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in I. T. Misc. Case No. 424 of 1959.
s. 10 2  xv

concepts.interpretation: Salary paid to Karta deductible if under valid agreement made on behalf of all members, in interest of business, justified by commercial expediency, wholly and exclusively for business purpose, bona fide, genuine, reasonable and not excessive.

anchor.surface_text: s. 10  2   xv  oft he Income-tax Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Deduction allowable for any expenditure laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business.

anchor.surface_text: s. 10  2   xv  of the Income-tax Act

concepts.unlisted_description: Deduction allowable for any expenditure laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has taken the view that under the Hindu Law, a karta is bound by reason of his being the karta to manage all the business of the family without being entitled to any remuneration for the service of management. It went on to comment that indeed, when under the law a karta represents the family, it would be anomalous to think of a karta as being an employee of himself or being entitled to remuneration for acting as such and receiving payment from his ownself.

concepts.interpretation: Karta ordinarily not entitled to remuneration for management but entitled under valid special agreement with family members.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Sarkar Sastris Hindu Law, 1940 Edn., N. E. Raghavachariars Hindu Law, 4th Edn., and Maynes Hindu Law, II th Edn., and in addition, on a decision of t

concepts.unlisted_description: Karta bound to manage family business without remuneration except under special arrangement or agreement.

anchor.surface_text: In judging what is a valid or proper agreement which would justify the payment of remuneration paid to a karta of the Hindu undivided family for managing the business of the family to be deductible as an expenditure under s. 10  2   xv  of the Income-tax Act, the test, we think, which should be applied, is whether the agreement has been made by or on behalf of all the members of the Hindu undivided family

concepts.interpretation: Valid agreement for Karta remuneration if made by/on behalf of all competent family members, including representing minors.

anchor.surface_text: The test of the validity of an agreement on behalf of a minor is that it should be for the benefit of the minor, and in this case, there is no finding that the agreement entered into on behalf of the Hindu undivided family including the minors by Babu Ram and Gobardhandas was in any way prejudicial to the interests of the minor members.

concepts.interpretation: Agreement on behalf of minor valid if for benefit of the minor and not prejudicial to interests.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ade. If the agreement is held to be in the interest of the family, the agreement would number be invalidated when executed on behalf of the minors by

anchor.surface_text: in our view, if a remuneration is paid to the karta of the family under a valid agreement which is bonafide and in the interest of, and expedient for, the business of the family and the payment is genuine and not excessive, such remuneration must be held to be an expenditure laid out wholly And exclusively for the purpose of the business of the family

concepts.unlisted_description: Criteria for allowing deduction: valid, bona fide agreement with reasonable payment.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the salary paid or credited to a Karta of the family for looking after the familys business was a permissible deduction under s. 10 2 xv in computing the income of the family business.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the salary paid or credited to a Karta of the family for looking after the familys business was a permissible deduction under s. 10 2  xv  in companyputing the income of the family business.

issues.text: In judging what is a valid or proper agreement which would justify the payment of remuneration paid to a karta of the Hindu undivided family for managing the business of the family to be deductible as an expenditure under s. 10 2 xv of the Income-tax Act, whether the agreement has been made by or on behalf of all the members of the Hindu undivided family and whether it was in the interest of the business of the family, so that it could be justified on grounds of commercial expediency.

anchor.surface_text: In judging what is a valid or proper agreement which would justify the payment of remuneration paid to a karta of the Hindu undivided family for managing the business of the family to be deductible as an expenditure under s. 10  2   xv  of the Income-tax Act, the test, we think, which should be applied, is whether the agreement has been made by or on behalf of all the members of the Hindu undivided family

issues.text: Whether the agreement entered into on behalf of the Hindu undivided family including the minors by Babu Ram and Gobardhandas was valid on behalf of the minor members, being for the benefit of the minor and not prejudicial to their interests.

anchor.surface_text: The test of the validity of an agreement on behalf of a minor is that it should be for the benefit of the minor, and in this case, there is no finding that the agreement entered into on behalf of the Hindu undivided family including the minors by Babu Ram and Gobardhandas was in any way prejudicial to the interests of the minor members.

issues.text: Whether the remuneration paid to Babu Ram was reasonable, commensurate with services rendered, genuine, bona fide and not excessive.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is no indication of any finding that the payment to Babu Ram was at all high, or was not commensurate with the services rendered by him.

issues.text: Whether the remuneration was paid only for managing the Hindu undivided family business or also for services to other partnership businesses.

anchor.surface_text: The language used was that Babu Ram should receive the remuneration for managing all the businesses of the Hindu undivided family, which can only mean that he was to manage the affairs of the Hindu undivided family firm and also to look after the interests of the Hindu undivided family in other businesses.

arguments.claim: Under Hindu law, a karta is bound to manage family business without remuneration

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has taken the view that under the Hindu Law, a karta is bound by reason of his being the karta to manage all the business of the family without being entitled to any remuneration for the service of management.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Sarkar Sastris Hindu Law, 1940 Edn., N. E. Raghavachariars Hindu Law, 4th Edn., and Maynes Hindu Law, II th Edn., and in addition, on a decision of t

arguments.court_reasoning: Hindu law texts and cases allow remuneration under special agreement with qualifications

arguments.claim: Anomalous for karta to be employee of himself and receive payment from self

anchor.surface_text: It went on to comment that indeed, when under the law a karta represents the family, it would be anomalous to think of a karta as being an employee of himself or being entitled to remuneration for acting as such and receiving payment from his ownself.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Sarkar Sastris Hindu Law, 1940 Edn., N. E. Raghavachariars Hindu Law, 4th Edn., and Maynes Hindu Law, II th Edn., and in addition, on a decision of t

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreement makes it valid expenditure under tax law despite position

arguments.claim: Karta not entitled to remuneration absent valid special agreement

anchor.surface_text: The Madras High Court in the case of Krishnaswami Ayyangar v. Rajagopala Ayyangar held that the managing partner was not entitled to special remuneration in the absence of a valid special agreement.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f the Madras High Court and the views expressed by these companymentators do number show that a Karta of a Hindu undivided family is number entitled t

arguments.court_reasoning: Recognizes possibility under valid agreement, which exists here

arguments.claim: Jitmal Bhuramal case distinguishable as it involved junior members not karta

anchor.surface_text: Mr. S. T. Desai, learned counsel appearing for the department tried to distinguish that case on the ground that in that case the salaries which were held to be deductible were paid to junior member of the family and not to the karta.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ny member of a Hindu undivided family including a karta can have a separate personal source of income if that income is earned independently of the Hi

arguments.court_reasoning: Jitmal principle general, no distinction between karta and junior; karta can receive for services

arguments.claim: Valid agreement for karta remuneration requires made by/on behalf of all family members and justified by commercial expediency

anchor.surface_text: In judging what is a valid or proper agreement which would justify the payment of remuneration paid to a karta of the Hindu undivided family for managing the business of the family to be deductible as an expenditure under s. 10 2 xv of the Income-tax Act, the test, we think, which should be applied, is whether the agreement has been made by or on behalf of all the members of the Hindu undivided family

arguments.claim: Deduction under s.10(2)(xv) if expenditure wholly and exclusively for business per commercial expediency test

anchor.surface_text: That is the test which has always to be applied when considering whether a particular expenditure claimed as a deduction under s. 10 2 xv of the Income-tax Act has been incurred wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business.

arguments.claim: Jitmal Bhuramal allows deduction of salary to family member if commercial expediency; applies to karta

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Jitmal Bhuramal v. Commissioner of Income-tax Bihar and Orissa has already held that a Hindu undivided family can be allowed to deduct salary paid to a member of the family, if the payment is made as a matter of commercial or business expediency.

arguments.claim: Agreement valid on behalf of minors if for their benefit and not prejudicial

anchor.surface_text: The test of the validity of an agreement on behalf of a minor is that it should be for the benefit of the minor, and in this case, there is no finding that the agreement entered into on behalf of the Hindu undivided family including the minors by Babu Ram and Gobardhandas was in any way prejudicial to the interests of the minor members.

arguments.claim: No finding payment excessive or not commensurate with services

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is no indication of any finding that the payment to Babu Ram was at all high, or was not commensurate with the services rendered by him.

arguments.claim: Remuneration for managing HUF businesses only, not partnership firms; distinguishes Jitmal

anchor.surface_text: The language used was that Babu Ram should receive the remuneration for managing all the businesses of the Hindu undivided family, which can only mean that he was to manage the affairs of the Hindu undivided family firm and also to look after the interests of the Hindu undivided family in other businesses.

arguments.claim: Agreement evidenced by later conduct: minors attained majority without challenge, treated as separate asset in partition

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the facts found show that some of the minors subsequently attained majority and none of them challenged the validity of this agreement... the amount to the credit of Babu Ram in the accounts was treated as his separate asset and was not included in the assets of the Hindu undivided family without any objection

arguments.claim: Remuneration deductible if under bona fide valid agreement, in interest of business, genuine, not excessive

anchor.surface_text: in our view, if a remuneration is paid to the karta of the family under a valid agreement which is bonafide and in the interest of, and expedient for, the business of the family and the payment is genuine and not excessive, such remuneration must be held to be an expenditure laid out wholly And exclusively for the purpose of the business of the family

arguments.claim: Remuneration paid also for partnership services, not deductible for HUF

anchor.surface_text: An alternative ground, on which Mr. Desai on behalf of the department challenged this deduction under s. 10 2 xv , was that the remuneration was being paid to Babu Ram not only ... but also for other businesses, including those of the partnership firms in which Babu Ram was a partner

court_response_anchor.surface_text: umber merely for looking after the Hindu undivided family business, but also for rendering services to the partnership firms in which Babu Ram was a p

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreement language covers only HUF businesses and interests therein

holdings.text: The salary paid or credited to a Karta of the family for looking after the familys business was a permissible deduction under s. 10(2)(xv) in computing the income of the family business.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the salary paid or credited to a Karta of the family for looking after the familys business was a permissible deduction under s. 10 2  xv  in companyputing the income of the family business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement valid, bona fide, in interest of business, reasonable, for HUF business services; deductible per commercial expediency test and Jitmal precedent.

holdings.text: Valid agreement for remuneration to Karta requires it to be made by or on behalf of all family members and justified by commercial expediency in interest of family business.

anchor.surface_text: In judging what is a valid or proper agreement which would justify the payment of remuneration paid to a karta of the Hindu undivided family for managing the business of the family to be deductible as an expenditure under s. 10  2   xv  of the Income-tax Act, the test, we think, which should be applied, is whether the agreement has been made by or on behalf of all the members of the Hindu undivided family

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies commercial expediency test under s.10(2)(xv); consistent with Hindu law allowing under special agreement.

holdings.text: Agreement by Babu Ram and Gobardhandas valid on behalf of minors as for their benefit with no finding of prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: The test of the validity of an agreement on behalf of a minor is that it should be for the benefit of the minor, and in this case, there is no finding that the agreement entered into on behalf of the Hindu undivided family including the minors by Babu Ram and Gobardhandas was in any way prejudicial to the interests of the minor members.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Benefit to minor test satisfied; later conduct (no challenge on majority, partition treatment) confirms validity.

holdings.text: Payment to Babu Ram reasonable and commensurate with services as no finding it excessive.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is no indication of any finding that.the payment to Babu Ram was at all high, or was not commensurate with the services rendered by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of adverse finding; applies reasonableness standard from precedents like Patna case.

holdings.text: Remuneration for managing all businesses of HUF, including interests in partnerships, not for separate partnership services.

anchor.surface_text: The language used was that Babu Ram should receive the remuneration for managing all the businesses of the Hindu undivided family, which can only mean that he was to manage the affairs of the Hindu undivided family firm and also to look after the interests of the Hindu undivided family in other businesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of agreement distinguishes from Jitmal where services to external firm.

holdings.text: Karta entitled to remuneration under valid special agreement despite general Hindu law duty to manage without pay.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Madras High Court and the views expressed by these commentators do not show that a Karta of a Hindu undivided family is not entitled to charge for services rendered to the family business under any circumstances at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hindu law texts and cases qualify absolute bar; allows under agreement; Jitmal principle extends to Karta.

holdings.text: Jitmal Bhuramal principle applies to remuneration to Karta, no distinction from junior members.

anchor.surface_text: The view expressed by this Court was in general terms and did not make any distinction between a junior member of the family or a karta.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects respondent's distinction; general principle of commercial expediency governs.

anchor.surface_text: Krishnswami Ayyangar v. Rajagopala Ayyangar.  1  It was on the basis of these comments in the books of Hindu Law that the Allahabad High Court held the view that Babu Ram, being the karta of the family, was number entitled to draw any remuneration for carrying on the business of the Hindu undivided family.

precedents.cited_holding: managing partner was not entitled to special remuneration in the absence of a valid special agreement

anchor.surface_text: Jitmal Bhuramal v. Commissioner of Income-tax Bihar and Orissa  1  has already held that a Hindu undivided family can be allowed to deduct salary paid to a member of the family, if the payment is made as a matter of companymercial or business expediency. Mr. S. T. Desai, learned companynsel appearing for the department tried to distinguish that case on the ground that in that case the salaries which were held to be deductible were paid to junior member of the family and number to the karta.

precedents.cited_proposition: reasonable remuneration paid by joint family to member for services is deductible if not excessive

Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa. 3 . precedents.cited_proposition: remuneration to family members for services to partnership firm (not family business) not deductible from family income
